verses.text: So I ask: Has God rejected His people? Absolutely not! For I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, from the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.comment: Paul insists that God’s promises remain for Israel. See also 1 Samuel 12:22 and Psalm 94:14 for God's faithfulness to His people.

verses.text: God has not rejected His people whom He foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says in the passage about Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?
verses.comment: Paul references Elijah complaining about Israel, yet God’s covenant remains. 'Foreknew' supports the doctrine of predestination and divine election.

verses.text: "Lord, they have killed Your prophets, they have demolished Your altars, and I alone am left, and they seek my life."
verses.comment: Paul cites Elijah’s despair as recorded in 1 Kings 19, showing even prophets felt abandoned, yet God preserved a remnant.

verses.text: But what is the divine response to him? "I have kept for Myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal."
verses.comment: Remnant theology: Just as in Elijah’s day, God preserves a faithful group—even in times of widespread rejection.

verses.text: So too at the present time, there is a remnant chosen by grace.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes grace as the means of election, paralleling Isaiah’s prophecy of the remnant. Divine initiative over human merit is stressed.

verses.text: And if it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works; otherwise, grace would no longer be grace.
verses.comment: This verse distinguishes grace from works in salvation. Yet, the faithful response includes obedient cooperation (cf. James 2:24).

verses.text: What then? Israel failed to obtain what it was seeking. The chosen obtained it, but the rest were hardened.
verses.comment: God’s election brings about a distinction—some are hardened as Pharaoh was (Exodus 7:3); others receive mercy (Romans 9:18).

verses.text: As it is written, "God gave them a spirit of stupor, eyes that would not see and ears that would not hear, down to this very day."
verses.comment: Paul merges Isaiah 29:10 and Deut. 29:4. Divine hardening as judgment for persistent unbelief.

verses.text: And David says, "Let their table become a snare and a trap, a stumbling block and a retribution for them;
verses.comment: Paul quotes Psalm 69:22, a messianic psalm. The table—often a sign of blessing—becomes judgment for rejecting Christ.

verses.text: "Let their eyes be darkened so that they cannot see, and bend their backs forever."
verses.comment: Continuation of the Psalm 69 quotation—a prayer for judgment in response to hardness of heart.

verses.text: So I ask: Did they stumble so as to fall beyond recovery? Certainly not! But through their failure, salvation has come to the Gentiles, to make Israel jealous.
verses.comment: Israel’s rejection enabled Gentile inclusion (Acts 13:46). Their ‘jealousy’ is meant to invite them back to faith—a reflection of God’s plan for unity in worship.

verses.text: Now if their failure brought riches for the world, and their defeat riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their full inclusion bring?
verses.comment: Paul foresees future reconciliation for Israel. The Church’s fullness includes both Gentile and Jew, foreshadowing the final unity of God’s people.

verses.text: Now I am speaking to you Gentiles: Inasmuch then as I am an apostle to the Gentiles, I honor my ministry,
verses.comment: Paul’s unique mission to the Gentiles serves a divine purpose. Ministry is also a means of sanctification for the world.

verses.text: in order to make my own people jealous, and thus save some of them.
verses.comment: Paul’s mission to the Gentiles is not an abandonment of Israel but meant to draw Israel back to the fold—unity is ultimately the plan.

verses.text: For if their rejection means reconciliation for the world, what will their acceptance mean but life from the dead?
verses.comment: The acceptance of Israel foreshadows resurrection life and deeper communion among God’s people (cf. Ezekiel’s ‘dry bones’ prophecy).

verses.text: If the first part of the dough offered as firstfruits is holy, then the whole lump is holy; and if the root is holy, so are the branches.
verses.comment: Paul uses sacrificial imagery to show how consecration of a part sanctifies the whole—an image pointing to the transmission of holiness via succession.

verses.text: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, though a wild olive shoot, were grafted in among them and now share in the nourishing root of the olive tree,
verses.comment: Gentiles are grafted into the root heritage of Israel. The covenant community is unified by sharing in the same root, not replacing it.

verses.text: do not boast over those branches. But if you do, remember: it is not you who support the root, but the root that supports you.
verses.comment: Gentiles should remember that salvation comes from the Jewish faith—there’s a call to humility and gratitude. John 4:22 affirms this role.

verses.text: Then you will say, 'Branches were broken off so that I might be grafted in.'
verses.comment: Paul voices a possible objection—Gentile believers must resist triumphalism, remembering their place within God’s inclusive plan.

verses.text: That is true. They were broken off because of unbelief, and you stand by faith. So do not be arrogant, but fear.
verses.comment: Faith enables inclusion among God’s people. The warning to ‘fear’ conveys the seriousness of remaining in God’s grace—perseverance is key.

verses.text: For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will He spare you.
verses.comment: Paul warns against complacency; ongoing steadfast faith is necessary to remain in God’s favor.

verses.text: Note then the kindness and severity of God: severity toward those who have fallen, but God’s kindness to you, if you continue in His kindness; otherwise you too will be cut off.
verses.comment: Divine kindness and severity depend on continued faithfulness. Final perseverance plays a significant role in salvation.

verses.text: And even they, if they do not continue in unbelief, will be grafted in, for God is able to graft them in again.
verses.comment: God’s mercy always allows for restoration—repentance leads to being welcomed back into the covenant family.

verses.text: For if you were cut from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and grafted, contrary to nature, into a cultivated tree, how much more will these, the natural branches, be grafted back into their own olive tree?
verses.comment: The natural descendants have a unique bond—reaffirming the continuity of God’s people through history.

verses.text: Brothers, I do not want you to be ignorant of this mystery, so that you will not be wise in your own estimation: a hardening has come upon part of Israel, until the full number of the Gentiles has come in.
verses.comment: The inclusion of the Gentiles is both a mystery and fulfillment of prophecy—reflects God’s universal plan for salvation.

verses.text: And so all Israel will be saved, as it is written: "The Deliverer will come from Zion; He will remove ungodliness from Jacob."
verses.comment: Quoting Isaiah 59:20, Paul affirms the messianic hope—God saves through the promised Deliverer, Christ.

verses.text: "And this will be My covenant with them when I take away their sins."
verses.comment: Echoes Jeremiah’s prophecy of a new covenant—fulfilled in Christ’s sacrifice which takes away sin (Hebrews 8:8-12).

verses.text: From the standpoint of the gospel, they are enemies for your sake, but from the standpoint of election, they are beloved for the sake of the ancestors.
verses.comment: God’s continued love for Israel rests on His promises to the patriarchs. The gracious divine plan works even through human failings.

verses.text: For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.
verses.comment: God does not abandon His promises. The Church’s ministry and sacraments rest on the security of God’s call.

verses.text: Just as you once were disobedient to God but now have received mercy because of their disobedience,
verses.comment: Gentile mercy arises out of Israel’s disobedience, suggesting that God works through every situation to invite more to His mercy.

verses.text: so they too have now been disobedient in order that by the mercy shown to you they too may now receive mercy.
verses.comment: God’s plan is to have mercy on all—Gentile salvation is meant to provoke Israel’s return, and build unity among believers.

verses.text: For God has consigned all to disobedience so that He may have mercy on all.
verses.comment: This universal plan expresses God’s generosity—highlighting God’s mercy as available to the whole world through Christ.

verses.text: Oh, the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments and how inscrutable His ways!
verses.comment: Paul’s doxology reflects the profound mystery of God’s will—God’s wisdom exceeds human understanding.

verses.text: "For who has known the mind of the Lord, or who has been His counselor?"
verses.comment: Paul quotes Isaiah 40:13 and Job 15:8—God’s ways are above ours, reminding us to approach Him with humility.

verses.text: "Or who has ever given to Him, that He should be repaid?"
verses.comment: Salvation is not earned by merit—everything is grace, an undeserved gift. God owes nothing, but gives all.

verses.text: For from Him and through Him and for Him are all things. To Him be glory forever! Amen.
verses.comment: A majestic doxology, echoing the supremacy of Christ over all creation (Colossians 1:16, Revelation 4:11). Glory is the fitting response to God’s wisdom and mercy.
